moves.1. d4: I am annotating this for two friends from Oswestry, who were playing each other on Gameknot.
moves.1... Nf6 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3:
So it starts very conventionally. Now d7-d5 would lead to the Orthodox Line of the Queen's Gambit Declined. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Queen%27s_Gambit_Declined
Or Bf8-b4 is the Nimzo-Indian Defence https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nimzo-Indian_Defence
moves.3... c5: This is quite playable too. Now 4. d4-d5 leads to Benoni systems.
moves.4. Nf3: But white doesn't go for that.
moves.4... cxd4: And Black prevents the pawn advance.
moves.5. Qxd4: I personally think this is the wrong way to recapture, as it allows black to develop the Nb8 with an attack on the white queen, gaining time.
moves.5... Nc6: Like this. I think this looks a bit like an English opening now.
moves.6. Qd1: The queen returns to base, but Qf4 or Qh4 could well have been considered too.
moves.6... d5: Black advances in the centre, gaining space.
moves.8. Bg5: This is a mistake. White has to prevent further advance of the d pawn with e3.
moves.9... Qxf6: The correct way to recapture, as to not compromise the king side pawns.
moves.10. Ne4: 10. Nb5 was played instead in paulatica (1537) vs. fromluxembourg (1915), but white also lost. I don't think 10. Nb5 is an improvement.
moves.11... Qe5: Threatening the knight as the other knight is pinned.
moves.13. Nxd2: White has to take this way, or he loses the knight on e4.
moves.14. g3: White prepares to fianchetto the white squared bishop.
moves.14... d3: Another good attacking move, which gives white problems...
moves.15. b4: Which white doesn't meet in the best way. 15. e3 was better threatening to take the pawn on d3 with his bishop.
moves.15... Nd4: Black moves his knight into an attacking square.
moves.16. e3: But now this is too late. Rc1 was needed to save his queen.
moves.17. Qxc2: The queen is going to go.
moves.18. Rc1: White could have probably spared us these last moves.
moves.18... Qb2: Another great attacking move, winning move material.
moves.20... Rd8:
Now if the knight moves, Rd8 is mate. Faced with yet more material loss, white wisely resigned.
I thought this is extremely well played by black!
